instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message:
Clean board, all ports on both sides reboot when the voltage tries to get up to 20V, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> had a tiny amount of corrosion on pin 36 <SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q1</SIGNAL> but it was not shorted.

I checked for shorts on all rails found nothing bad.

LDO on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> are all measuring fine.

Components already replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and another component that often fails but it is not on the schematic I have, it is located next to the USB ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message: Check what happens if you connect known good charged battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message: With charged battery it turns on keeps 20V but 0A and wont charge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message:
Check if board starts with battery.
What you get then on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message:
Board starts and loads system with charged battery.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 11V

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message:
What is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with charger alone (no battery)?
If not present, check <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message:
Really strange, possibly bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.
Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages (charger alone); <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Power loops when it climbs to 20V
threads.message: Thanks, as soon as you mentioned <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> I remembered that pin 36 <SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q1</SIGNAL> goes directly to it and that was the pin that had corrosion on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> so I just replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and board works.
